He has been doing this business for 5 years in the district of Pimpingos and he has experience in growing coffee and good references from his neighbors. He also works raising cattle and small animals like chickens, ducks, guinea pigs, amongst others.

The loan will be used to buy manure and fertilizer to provide maintenance for his coffee crops to secure greater and higher production and in the end be able to improve his quality of living and that of his family.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertilizer to provide maintenance for his coffee crops.

loans.name: Biswa Trimuti Group-D

texts.en:
Biswa Trimuti Group-D was formed with 10 members in 2014 in a small village of Koraput district in Odisha. The members all came together to help each other, solve the social issues among them, save money and provide financial support to their families. They selected Laxmi as the leader of their group. 

Laxmi and Maina have requested this loan. The lady standing first from left is Laxmi and second one is Maina. These two women are the part of this group but they are requesting this loan separately.

Laxmi is a 44-year-old woman living with her husband and her two children. For the past seventeen years, Laxmi’s husband has been working as a farmer and earning 3,000 to 4,000 INR per month but it is not sufficient to manage the small family. So Laxmi is helping her husband by working with him and being involved in the milk business. She has six years of experience in this business. 

She has requested a loan to buy a cow and fodder so that she can support her family’s income. Laxmi says that by selling milk, she can support her family and she can send her children to a good school. Through that, she can provide a better education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and fodder and to build a cow shed.

loans.name: Maa Jagat Janani Shg-C Group

texts.en:
This group consists of two members, both of whom are women. These two entrepreneurs are very humble, hardworking and responsible people with good manners and lots of enthusiasm to improve their lives. A few years ago, both were facing poverty, so they planned to start a grocery shop where they can provide the basic household consumables to their customers.

One of the members is Sita, who was selected as the featured borrower. Sita is a 34-year-old lady living with her husband and her three children who are attending school. The lady standing on the right side in the photo is Sita.

She runs a grocery shop to help her husband financially. She sells rice, grains, lentils, edible oil, spices, biscuits, soap, detergent, hair oil, etc. in her shop. She has developed a very good relationship with her customers in the village. She likes the fact that she can cater to the needs of the people in her village.

She has a plan to make her shop bigger and keep multiple things in her shop to satisfy her customers. She also wants to purchase the items for her shop in bulk directly from the wholesalers. For this reason, she has requested a loan to purchase items such as toothbrushes, toothpaste, soft drinks, wheat flour, grains, and other household consumables.

loans.use: to purchase toothbrushes, toothpaste, soft drinks, wheat flour, grains, and other household consumables for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Martha Cecilia

texts.es:
Martha se dedica a la actividad de la confección desde hace aproximadamente 15 años, gracias a esto ha podido contribuir al sostenimiento de los gastos de su hogar. 
Martha es soltera y vive en una casa sola, Martha decidió montar un taller donde ofrece el servicio de confección a terceros.  

Gracias a la buena calidad de las prendas que fabrica, ha podido captar una muy buena clientela, lo que le ha permitido tener muy buenas ventas. 

Trabaja todos los días durante 12 horas sola.

Martha actualmente quiere aumentar la capacidad de producción de su taller con el ánimo de poder salir adelante, es por esto que aspira a que un préstamo le brinde la oportunidad de acceder a la compra de materia prima como tela.

Martha espera que de esta manera pueda cumplir su sueño de convertirse en una gran empresaria.

Martha espera que su taller aumente las ventas considerablemente y en un futuro hacerlo crecer y poder generar empleo para las personas más necesitadas. 

Ayuda con un préstamo el taller de Martha!
texts.en:
Martha has worked making clothing for about 15 years. Thanks to this she has been able to contribute to supporting the household expenses. Martha is single and lives alone in a house. Marta decided to start a workshop where she offers sewing services to third parties. Thanks to the good quality of the clothing she makes she has been able to garner a good clientele, which has allowed her to have very good sales. She works lone every day for 12 hours. Martha currently wants to increase the production capacity of her workshop with the aim of getting ahead.

For this reason she hopes to get a loan to give her the opportunity to buy raw material like fabric. Martha hopes by doing this her workshop increase sales considerably and in the future grows and be able to generate employment for needy people. Help Martha's workshop with a loan.

loans.use: to buy raw material like fabric.

loans.name: Muktamani's Group

texts.en:
Chumuki is a 24-year-old married woman living with her parents-in-law, husband and a child in the Koraput District of Odisha, India. She is engaged in the activity of making and selling handmade wall hangings, cushion covers, paper bags, candles, purses, etc. She makes these items in her home and sells them to the dealers in the nearby market. Her husband is not financially strong enough to manage the family, so she helps her father manage the family expenses. 

Chumuki, along with Muktamani and Purnima, has requested a loan of 36,000 Indian rupees, and she will use her portion for purchasing fabrics, colors, paper, glue, glitters, decorative glass, wax, etc., in bulk so that she can make her crafts in a large amount. She also wants to appoint one more person, who can assist her in the business and help her to make more of the products. 

In the future, she wants to give training to the village girls about this art. She also has a dream of giving her parents a quality standard of living. 

Muktamani and Purnima are engaged in paddy (rice) cultivation.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing fabrics, colors, wax, glitters, glue, and decorative glass for doing her craft work.

loans.name: Jay Ganga Mata Group-D

texts.en:
Neela is a 34-year-old lady living with her husband, her son aged 8, and a daughter aged 5 years. She runs a snack stall in the market, which is 300 meters away from her house. She has years of experience in this activity. She sells snacks items like samosas (fried dough stuffed with potato curry), Idli (a popular recipe of South Indian origin made by steaming a batter consisting of fermented black lentils and rice), Wada (a lentil doughnut), etc., in her shop. 

Neela wants to expand her business by selling more of the items she sells now and to make a showcase for her shop to display the products she cooks. She says that doing so will attract more customers to her shop. 

She, along with Lakshmi, has requested a loan amount of 24,000 INR from which she will use her portion to purchase raw materials like potatoes, spices, edible oil, lentils, rice, etc., and for making a showcase for her shop. She has a dream: to have her children study in a good school and save some money for their future.

The lady standing on the right side in the photo is Neela.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing raw materials like potatoes, spices, edible oil, lentils, rice, etc., for her snack shop, and to make a showcase for the shop.

loans.name: Maa Tarini Group-D

texts.en:
"Maa Tarini Group-D" is a women's group with two members. The members reside in a small village of Koraput district in Odisha, India. 

The lady standing on the left in the photograph is Radha. Radha is the featured borrower of the group. Radha, 45, and her husband, 49, have two children who are currently in school. For eight years, this husband and wife have worked as a team selling fresh and dried fish in the market. Her husband goes to the large lake near to her village to fish and brings home the hard-earned products of his labor, while Radha prepares dried fish to sell in the local market. 

She hopes to get a loan to purchase fishing net and a storage box to store and transport the fish. With the ability to fish and store larger quantities of fish, she hopes to increase their profit.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and a storage box to store and transport more fish to sell in the local fish market.

loans.name: Maa Jagat Janani Shg-D Group

texts.en:
Sunamani and Dhanishta formed a group named Maa Jagat Janani Self-Help Group-D. Both the members are from the district of Koraput in Odisha, India. One of them is Sunamani, who was selected as their featured borrower. The lady standing on the right side in the photo is Sunamani.

Sunamani is 51 years old and is staying with her husband and her two children. Her husband is a farmer and has been involved in cultivation for a long time. She got the idea of doing paddy cultivation from her husband, so she contacted and shared her idea with Dhanishta. Dhanishta liked her idea and appreciated her. Then both started to cultivate paddy and sell it in her village.

Sunamani has very good relationships with her customers, as she sells paddy or rice, whichever is required by the customers, on time. Now she has a new idea, which is to lease more land for cultivation so that she can do paddy cultivation on a large scale. For this reason, she has requested a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay for leasing farmland.

loans.name: Jay Ganga Mata Group-A

texts.en:
The Jay Ganga Mata Group-A is a group of three women all living in the city of Jeypore, Koraput district of Odisha, India. Jeypore being only 1 km away from a big lake, villagers rely heavily on the lake for fishing and other seafood-related industries. 

Standing on the first from left in the photo, Bhabani is the featured borrower of the group. Bhabani lives with her fisherman husband. Bhabani and her group members request a loan of 36,000 INR to purchase fishing nets, iceboxes for fish storage, and preservatives to keep the fish fresh. 

The women also prepare dried fish along with fresh fish to sell in the local markets.

loans.use: to pay for fishing nets, iceboxes and preservatives

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.ru: Гульмира, 46 лет, замужем, мать 3 детей. Дети школьного возраста. По характеру Гульмира спокойная, трудолюбивая, доброжелательная. В качестве основного источника дохода для семьи, она занимается полеводством и животноводством. Имеет развитое хозяйство, а именно 20 овец, лошадь и корову, а также на земельном наделе мерою 2,0 ГА она выращивает фасоль. Гульмира получает ежемесячную прибыль в сумме около 10,000 сом (KGS). Она обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коровы. Доходы от кредита Гульмира планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение своего хозяйства и образование ее детей.
texts.en:
Gulmira is 46 and married with three school-aged children. She is a calm, hardworking and kind person who works in animal husbandry and agriculture as the primary source of income for her family. She has a well-developed farm that includes 20 sheep, a horse, a cow and 2 hectares of land where she grows beans. She receives a monthly income of about 10,000 KGS.

Gulmira has approached Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 50,000 KGS to purchase a cow. She plans to put profits from the loan into further building up her farm and into her children's education.

loans.use: to buy a cow in order to increase her herd

loans.name: Carmen Lucia

texts.es:
Carmen es una microempresaria dedicada y trabajadora, su campo de acción es la confección, prestando el servicio a terceros.
Todo comenzó hace muchos años cuando trabajaba como operaria en un taller de confección; hoy en día, a sus 59 años de edad, ya tiene su propio taller en el que genera 1 empleo directo; trabaja todos los días y su fortaleza es la fabricación de pantalones y camisas de uniformes; de esta forma genera los recursos suficientes para apoyar a su esposo con la carga económica del hogar.
El crédito que solicita será invertido en la compra de tela e hilos, así podrá cumplir con los requerimientos de sus clientes y entregar los pedidos de manera oportuna, con el fin aumentar la producción y adquirir nuevos contratos, que permitan darle continuidad a su microempresa.

Carmen sueña con seguir fortaleciendo su taller y tener cada día mayor nivel de producción para generar nuevas oportunidades de empleo y mejorar la calidad de vida tanto de su familia como la de las personas que influyen diariamente en su labor.
texts.en:
Carmen is a devoted and hard-working small businesswoman.  Her line of work is sewing for third parties.  Everything started many years ago when she worked in a clothes making shop.  Now, at age 59, she has her own shop in which she generates direct employment for one person.  She works every day, and her strength is making uniform pants and shirts.  This way she generates enough resources to help her husband with the financial responsibilities of the household.

She will use the loan she is requesting to buy fabric and thread.  This way she will be able to meet her customers’ needs and deliver the orders in a timely fashion.  The result will be increasing production and getting new contracts, which will allow her to continue with her small business.

Carmen dreams of continuing to strengthen her shop.  She dreams of having a greater level of production each day in order to generate new employment opportunities and improve the quality of life for her family and for the people who contribute to her work every day.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread for her workshop.

loans.name: Maa Tarini Group-A

texts.en:
Maa Tarini Group-A has three members who are all from the same neighborhood. The lady standing first from the left hand side in the photo is Gori, who is the leader of the group.

Gori is 28 years old and married to a fisherman from a small village in Odisha, India. Gori lives with her in-laws, and her husband takes care of all the household expenses. She helps her husband sell fish. Her husband goes to the lake every morning to fish, and she sells those fish in the market as fresh fish and keeps some of them to dry (drying the fish is a way of preserving the fish for future use by drying them in the sun until the water is completely evaporated) and sells them as dried fish.

Demand for dried as well as fresh fish is very high in the region. All the members of this group are engaged in selling fresh and dried fish in the market. In order to strengthen the business and respond to client demands, Gori, along with Manima and Subhadra, has requested a loan of 36,000 INR to purchase fishing nets and storage boxes to keep fish. Their goal is to increase their business activity.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets and storage boxes to keep fish.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group-B

texts.en:
Anusuya, the lady standing first from the right, is a 41-year-old lady who lives with her husband and two children. Her children are in school. She is involved in an agricultural activity. This is not sufficient to manage her family, so she purchased a cow. Now she is taking care of her cow and selling milk in the local market. From this business, she earns 2,000 to 2,500 INR per month. She wants to purchase one more cow and continue her milk business. She has three years of experience in this field, and she has time to take care of the cows. 

Anusuya, along with Tilatama and Bimala, has requested a loan of 36,000 INR from which she will use her portion to purchase a jersey cow and fodder for her cows. She says that this business can strengthen her economic condition, and she can pay her children's tuition. She has a dream of educating her children so they can earn for themselves in the future. She does not want her children to face the same kinds of problems in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a jersey cow and fodder for her cows.

loans.name: Dana

texts.en:
Dana is from Irbid.  She is working hard to grow, study, and become a successful lady in the future. She has four siblings, who are in school studying.

Dana's goal is to finish her diploma degree which is in hospital management.  She wants to find a good job so she can help her family with the household expenses and her siblings' education. 

She is requesting this loan to pay her educational expenses. Her dad faced financial problems which prevented him from helping Dana pay her education fees.

loans.use: to pay her educational expenses.

loans.name: Topisha's Group

texts.en:
Topisha is 31 years old and is often described as a very trustworthy person. She has 4 children and is married. As a group leader, Topisha is representing her group of 10 farmers in Webuye District, Kenya. She is very excited to be working with One Acre Fund for the first time this year.

The decision to join One Acre Fund was largely a result of Topisha's desire to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. Apart from receiving farming inputs, she is also purchasing a solar light as part of her loan, which is very exciting to her.  She will now be able to reduce the consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money. With the profits that she gains from this year’s harvest, she plans to save more money for the future.

Topisha and her group will receive a total of 9 solar lights as well as input loans of maize and fertilizer to plant a total of 4.25 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group-A

texts.en:
Kamala, the lady standing first from the left in the photograph, is a 41-year-old widow lady living with her daughter, age 13, and son, age 9. Her son is studying, and her daughter runs a small tailoring shop where she does repair work on the dresses of her customers. 

Kamala owns and manages a variety store where she sells sarees (traditional Indian dresses), bangles, cosmetics, talcum powder, fashion accessories, etc. She has a plan to enhance her business by bringing in more stock of what she sells and adding some more products like wafers, nail colors, falls (used to attach to the bottom of sarees), shampoos, hair oil, etc. She says that doing so will improve her family’s economic condition. 

Kamala, along with her group, has requested a loan of 36,000 Indian rupees (INR) for her group to purchase the above products. She has a dream of giving a good education to her son and saving some money for her daughter’s marriage.

loans.use: to pay for purchasing bangles, cosmetics, talcum powder, wafers, nail colors, shampoos, etc., for her variety store.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group-C

texts.en:
Bhanupriya is 20 years old and lives with her husband, her husband's siblings and her parents-in-law in a small village of the Koraput district of Odisha. She owns a grocery shop where she sells biscuits, wafers, toffees, cakes, bread, etc. In this way, she earns 3,000 INR per month, which is not sufficient to manage her big family. She is unable to provide the minimum study materials to her husband's siblings. 

She wants to increase her business and set up a shop in her home. She has requested a loan of 12,000 INR for each group member. She will set up a shop in her home, purchase goods in bulk and add some new varieties of stationery items and snacks for her shop. 

The lady standing on the left in photo is Bhanupriya.

loans.use: to establish a shop and purchase biscuits, wafers, toffees, and cakes to sell.

loans.name: Maa Mangala Group-D

texts.en:
Mulabati is a 42-year-old widow woman living with her parents, brother and a daughter who is 8 years old. After her husband’s death, she came back to her paternal house, started living with her parents and got herself engaged in tutoring the village kids. She earns 2,000 INR per month from this activity, but this is not sufficient for her to run her family. 

She has a plan to start a ladies' novelty corner in her house, where she will keep cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo, body talc, body deodorant, bangles and other fashion accessories. She says that doing so will improve her earnings and her family’s status. 

She has requested a loan of 12,000 INR for each member, and she will use her portion to purchase the above-mentioned items for her ladies' novelty corner. She dreams of educating her daughter and saving money to make her future secure. 

The lady standing on the left in the photograph is Mulabati.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics, hair oil, shampoo, body talc, body deodorant, bangles and other fashion accessories to sell

loans.name: Epouses Des Enseignants N°4" Gie Yokouté 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le GIE « Epouses des enseignants n°4 », regroupent des femmes enseignantes et/ou dont les maris sont enseignants. Ce rassemblement est né il y a quelques années et les activités divergent selon les membres.
La responsable s’appelle Catherine Sophie, âgée de 27 ans elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants, une fille et un garçon  âgés respectivement de 2 ans et 5 ans. Elle est enseignante de profession depuis 2008, mais pratique le commerce depuis 2 ans. Son commerce qui consiste à vendre des tissus, des chaussures autour d’elle et auprès de ces collègues.
Comme charges, elle s’occupe de payer les factures d’eau.
Comme projet, elle rêve d’avoir sa propre boutique d’alimentation générale.
texts.en:
The borrowers’ group "Teachers’ spouses #4" is composed of women who either are teachers themselves and/or are married to teachers. This group was created a few years ago, and its members are engaged in various types of business activities.

The name of the group’s leader is Catherine Sophie. She is 27 years old, married and has two children, a girl and a boy, two and five years of age, respectively. She has become a teacher in 2008 but she also  has been working as a vendor for two years. She sells fabric and shoes in her community and to her co-workers. She takes care of paying the water bills. Her goal for the future is to open her own grocery store.

loans.use: to buy shoes and fabric for resale.

loans.name: Bimala's Group

texts.en:
Bimala is a 42-year-old woman who lives with her son, age 19 years, in a small village of Odisha, India. Her son goes for schooling in a government school near her house.

Bimala is engaged in a tailoring business and garments business. Her son helps her in her garment business as well as in her tailoring business, as he purchases sewing materials and garments from the big city.

Bimala wants to expand her business, and for that she has applied for a loan of 12,000 INR for each member to purchase a new sewing machine, thread, cloth, etc. She hopes to make more money after this investment, and she is thankful to Kiva for this kind help and support.

The lady standing first from the left in the photo is Bimala.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine, thread, cloth, etc.

loans.name: Maa Thakurani Group-B

texts.en:
Mukta, the lady standing first from the left in the photo, is a 36-year-old woman who lives with her husband, parents-in-law, and two children in a village called Mundipadar in the Koraput district of Odisha, India. Her children go to a government school near her house.

She owns a chicken center where she sells chicken meat, and she runs a tea stall where she sells tea, biscuits, and some snack items. Her elder son helps her in this business.

She wants to open a fast food corner where she can sell noodles, rolls, etc. She has applied for a loan to purchase a refrigerator, a showcase, a gas cylinder, and raw materials to make fast food. She has committed to pay back her loan on time.

She is happy and thankful to Kiva for this kind opportunity.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator, a showcase, a gas cylinder, and raw materials to make fast food.

loans.name: Noel

texts.en: Noel faces considerable preparation for the post-harvest operations of his palay (rice) farm in Bagacay, Sibutad.  He wants to ensure that he will have ample time for the threshing, drying, storage and processing of his harvest to make way for another cropping season. He presented his loan proposal to Paglaum MPC. Noel hopes to have his own family someday.

loans.use: to pay for labor for the post-harvest of rice, such as the threshing, drying, storage and processing of his harvest

loans.name: Marmolinia

texts.en:
Marmolinia is a strong-willed woman who pushes her ability when it comes to her piggery business. She is a hands-on businesswoman and mother who never gets tired of working to support her family. 

Recently, Marmolinia requested a loan to purchase bags of feed and animal vitamins for her growing hogs in order to boost her income. Aside from her project of building additional pig pens, she has thought of adding heads of pigs for commercial sale and plans to take in swine production for her business expansion. Someday, Marmolinia hopes to open a meat shop in a nearby town

loans.use: to purchase bags of feeds and animal vitamins

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is 55 years old and lives in D'ban, Calamba, Philippines. She is married with five children. She sells fruits and vegetables to earn a living and has had this business for five years. She has requested a loan to purchase more fruits to sell. Anita has been a member of PMPC for three years. In the future, she hopes to save for emergencies.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios is 64 years old and lives in D'ban, Calamba, Philippines. She is married and has four children. Remedios has a piggery business, a business she has had for five years. She requested a loan to buy one piglet and one sack of feed for added income. She has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Remedios hopes to increase her income.

loans.use: to buy one piglet and one sack of feed

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan had helped her business. She was able to purchase additional grocery products needed to increase her product inventory. The loan also helped her provide for her daily needs and expenditures.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you will lend her an amount of 15,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional stocks of groceries, toiletries, and beverages. Her customers will likely buy more items if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales will also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family.

Janet hopes to be able to save for her family and dreams of expanding her business soon. She meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of groceries and other supplies for her store

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is a very hardworking entrepreneur from Pasay City, Philippines. She is 49 years old and has children. She solely supports her children through all of her hard work. She operates a junk shop to provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines and while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, and papers. They sell these items to junk shops for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean, and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries and factories. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Marissa is taking out a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy recyclable materials from collectors. 

In the future, she dreams to expand her business. She also operates a business that buys and sells frozen foods and she desires that this business will thrive more. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy recyclable materials from collectors

loans.name: Andrada

texts.en: Andrada is 60 years old and married with five children. For two years, she has earned a living by raising chickens in the Philippines. She earns additional income working in a computer shop. Andrada is borrowing 25,000 PHP through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, to buy feed and other supplies to raise her chickens. She is working tirelessly toward her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and other supplies to raise her chickens

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda is 48 years old and a married woman. For five years, she has been buying and selling coconut wine in the Philippines. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Erlinda requested a 12,000 PHP loan through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, to buy containers of coconut wine to sell. In the future, Erlinda would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy containers of coconut wine to sell

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia is a 57-year-old, married woman. She has seven children who are in school. For the past year, Lucia has been buying and reselling rice in the Philippines. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Lucia requested a 5000 PHP loan through Kiva's partner, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, to buy sacks of rice to sell in her business. In the future, Lucia would like to save enough money so she can send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to sell in her business

loans.name: Sobie

texts.en:
This is 48-year-old Sobie. She is married and has three children aged 30, 26 and 20. She has two additional dependents, who live with her to be fostered. In 2005, Sobie established her drinks, bread, tea and rice business. She started the business just after she completed her catering course. Her husband provided the capital to start the business and to meet her family needs in the meantime. Her main customers are student and neigbhours. Working six days a week and 12 hours a day, he earns about SLL 1,135,000 every month from her business. 

Sobie would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Sobie has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more crates of soft drinks, assorted provisions and bags of rice. The previous loan has helped improve her business and her living standard as well. She hopes that this loan will help to expand her business and generate more income, and that it will also help to achieve her future plans. In the future, Sobie still plans to expand the business and provide quality education for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for crate of soft drink, assorted provision and bags of rice

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena is a married woman with seven children, three of whom are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Rowena is 39 years old.

Rowena has a general store business in the Philippines. Rowena requested an 8,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy items to sell in her general store like canned goods, shampoo, home product care, groceries, etc.

Rowena has been in this business for three years. In the future, Rowena would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store like canned goods, shampoo, home product care, groceries, etc

loans.name: Sanaa

texts.en:
Sanaa 50 years old and lives in Zarqa. She is a conservative woman, so she asked her daughter to take her place in the photo.

She has three children who are university students. She has a dream, which is to see her children be successful and unique.

Her daughter is majoring foreign languages: she is working hard to complete her education and find a good job with a good salary. 

Recently, Sanaa has faced financial problems, so she could not pay for her daughter's education fees. Therefore she applied for an education loan to pay for her daughter's university fees.

loans.use: To pay her daughter's university fees

loans.name: Jagat Janani Group-B

texts.en:
Sariphan is 43 years old and a widow living with her father and two children in a small village of Koraput district in Odisha, India. She has been engaged in selling bangles and ladies' personal-care products after the death of her husband. Her husband expired in 2009. 

Sariphan's father helps her in her business, as he purchases items from the market and gives them to Sariphan. Sariphan sells her stock in nearby village markets. She earns 3,000 INR per month from this activity. She has a plan to take a room for rent and open a variety store where she can sell ladies' personal-care products. 

She, along with her group members, has requested a loan. She will use her portion to purchase different styles of bangles and other personal-care products in bulk. She hopes to make her daughter a teacher. She is happy and grateful to Kiva for this kind help.

In the photo, the lady standing on the left is Sariphan; in the middle is Sunamani; and on the right is Urmila.

loans.use: to purchase different styles of bangles and other personal-care products in bulk.

loans.name: Loan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Loan, born in 1980, is a woman of the Kinh ethnic majority. She has participated in the program of M7-MFI since January 2010. She currently lives with her husband and her two daughters in Mai Son district, Son La province.

Her family’s main occupation is breeding; the annual income from selling several pig herds, after deducting costs, is just enough for covering the expenses of her family and paying for her children’s education fees. Therefore, the amount of money she has saved is not enough to buy breeding stock and food for the next pig herd.

She hopes the loan amount will help her family invest effectively in breeding with high productivity, and the coming herd will bring her family a  considerable profit when sold. She will try to find an extra job to work to get money to repay the loan for M7-MFI on time.

loans.use: to buy breeding stock and food

loans.name: By His Grace Group

texts.en:
These ladies are part of the group By His Grace, which is composed of two individuals living in the same neighborhood. Their work encompasses such things as cloth, materials, pork meat, drinks, and cooked rice. 

The group’s representative, Kadijatu, is 52 years old. Kadijatu never attended school but has 13 years of work experience selling new wax prints (clothing), second hand clothing and materials. She is married and has one dependent child, who is in school. In order to provide for her child, Kadijatu (on the left in the photo) has been selling new wax prints, second hand clothing and materials. Kadijatu buys wax prints, second hand clothing and materials from the market in Ghana. 

With the goal of bolstering her business, Kadijatu, together with the other member of this group who is selling pork meat, drinks, and cooked rice, are seeking their seventh loan of 3,500 GHS from ID Ghana. Their prior loan has been duly repaid.

loans.use: to buy wax prints, second hand clothing and materials from the market in Ghana.

loans.name: Clement's Group

texts.en:
Clement, featured in the above picture, is representing his farming group made up of 12 farmers in Webuye District, Kenya. He is 55 years old and a married father of 6 children. He is often described as a very hardworking individual. 

Although Clement has been a farmer for more than 30 years, he is new to One Acre Fund. He decided to join this year because he really wanted to have access to quality training and to learn new farming methods. Even though he is new to the program, Clement wanted to represent his group because he wanted to help more farmers. With the profits earned from this season’s harvest, Clement hopes to be able to send his children to school.

With this loan, the group will receive farming inputs to cultivate a total of 6 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 12 solar lights, because, even though Clement decided not to, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light as part of their loan package.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Lan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lan, born in 1975, is a Thai ethnic woman. She has participated in the program of M7-MFI (before it was a social fund) since January 2000. She lives with her husband and her daughter in Mai Son district, Son La province.

Her family’s main income is from livestock breeding. Therefore, she has to sell miscellaneous goods to get additional income for the family and for feeding her daughter with food and education at school. Generally, the income is just enough to cover the expenses of the family with a small amount left. However, the saved amount is not enough to invest in pig raising and chicken breeding. Therefore, she wants to borrow a loan to invest in expanding the breeding.

She hopes the loan amount will help her family invest effectively in breeding with high productivity and quality. She hopes that when selling pigs and chickens, she can bring her family a considerable profit.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the breeding

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn has mastered her skills in making bread. She has her own unique bread recipe and she is known for her homemade sweet bread. This has kept her business going for more than five years now. Recently, Jocelyn requested a loan to buy more kilos of flour, sugar, and margarine for bread production. Jocelyn hopes to expand her business by displaying in more store outlets.

loans.use: to buy more kilos of flour, sugar, and margarine

loans.name: Cecilia Maritza

texts.es:
Cecilia tiene 41 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene un hijo, vive en casa propia en una zona rural que se encuentra ubicada en el distrito de Oyotún, provincia de Chiclayo, región Lambayeque, en la costa norte de Perú. La vida en este distrito se desarrolla tranquilamente y los pobladores se dedican a la agricultura, comercio y crianza de animales.

Ella se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales de corral como gallinas, patos, pavos, entre otros, se dedica a este negocio desde hace 10 años, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su mismo domicilio. Solicita préstamo para la compra de una mayor cantidad de animales como patos, gallinas, cuyes, entre otros, para incrementar el stock de su negocio, con esto Cecilia espera ofrecer una mayor variedad de animales a sus clientes lo que le permitirá satisfacer sus gustos y necesidades y tendrá un impacto positivo en su nivel de ingresos y por ende en su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Cecilia is 41 years old, is in a common-law relationship and has a son. She lives in her own house in a rural area that is located in the district of Oyotún, Chiclayo province, Lambayeque region, on the North Coast of Peru. Life in this district is peaceful and the inhabitants work in agriculture commerce and raising livestock.

Cecilia works raising and selling farmyard animals like chickens, ducks and turkeys, amongst others. She has worked in this business for 10 years and her business is located at her house. She is requesting a loan to buy a greater quantity of animals like ducks, chickens, guinea pigs amongst others to increase the stock of her business. Doing this Cecilia hopes to offer a greater variety of animals to her clients which would allow her to satisfy their tastes and needs and would have a positive impact on her level of income and in the end her quality of living.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of animals like ducks, chickens, guinea pigs, amongst others to increase the stock of her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 59 years old and widowed with five children. Elizabeth works very hard to provide for them.

Elizabeth runs a general store in the Philippines and requested an 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional items like canned goods, eggs, bread, coffee, noodles, cereals, etc. to sell.

Elizabeth has been in this business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, eggs, bread, coffee, noodles, cereals, etc. 

Elizabeth would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like canned goods, eggs, bread, coffee, noodles, cereals, etc. to sell

loans.name: Eme

texts.en:
Eme is a widowed woman with six children, one of whom is still in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Eme is 55 years old.

Eme has a general store business in the Philippines. Eme requested a 25,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Eme has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Eme would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is 27 years old and married with five children. With two children in school, Wilma works very hard to provide for them.

Wilma runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her general store like eggs, condiments, home care products, and other groceries.

Wilma has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as softdrinks, hopia, noodles, junk foods, and other groceries. 

In the future, Wilma would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store like eggs, condiments, home care products, and other groceries

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana is 50 years old and married with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Emeliana has a general store business in the Philippines. Emeliana requested a 15,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store business.

Emeliana has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Emeliana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
Ethel works hard to support her family.  She is married, and she has a business selling dried fish in the Philippines.

Ethel has requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Ethel has been in this business for three years now.  She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Ethel would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a vegetable-vending business in the Philippines. She also earns additional income from buying and selling frozen foods.

She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase more vegetables to sell to her customers for her vegetable-vending business.

NWTF is re-listing Evelyn's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora works hard to support her family.  She is widowed, and she has a bvusiness selling vegetables in the Philippines.

Flora has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall.

Flora has been in this business for 51 years now.  She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Flora would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall

loans.name: Geelyn

texts.en:
Geelyn has a live-in partner woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Geelyn is 33 years old and has three children who are currently in school.

Geelyn has a video gaming machine rental business in the Philippines. Geelyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her business, and she earns additional income from rental housing.

Geelyn has been in this business for 10 years. In the future, Geelyn would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 47 years old and married.  She works very hard to provide for her family.

Jocelyn runs a general store in the Philippines.  She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items like shampoo, detergent soap, eggs, canned goods, noodles, and coffee to sell.

Jocelyn has been in this business for 10 years.  She sells a variety of items such as shampoo, detergent soap, eggs, canned goods, noodles, and coffee. 

In the future, Jocelyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items like shampoo, detergent soap, eggs, canned goods, noodles, and coffee to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Marivic works hard to support her family.

She has a dried fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a clothing retail business. Marivic is borrowing PHP 26,000 through NWTF to buy more stocks of dried fish to resell.

Marivic has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of dried fish to resell.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Leonida is 57 years old and has one child who is still in school.

Leonida has a direct sales business selling Avon products in the Philippines. Leonida requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more products like lotion, deodorant, body spray, etc. to sell to her customers.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Leonida has been in this business for 10 years. Leonida would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more products like lotion, deodorant, body spray, etc. to sell to her customers

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine, featured in the above picture, is representing her farming group of 12 farmers in Webuye District, Kenya. She is 32 years old and is a married mother of 6 children. She is often described as a very friendly person. 

Although Christine has been a farmer for 13 years, she is new to One Acre Fund. She decided to join this year because she really wanted to have access to quality training and learn new farming methods. Even though she is new to the program, Christine wanted to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. With the profits earned from this season’s harvest, Christine hopes to be able to send her children to school.

With this loan, the group will receive farming inputs to cultivate a total of 6.5 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 11 solar lights, because, even though Christine decided not to, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light as part of their loan package.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Ana Leidy

texts.es:
Ana, en su incansable búsqueda de una mejor vida y una mejor estabilidad económica para su hija de 6 años, inicio con un negocio de arreglo de uñas y cepillado de cabello prestando su servicio en un pequeño local en el municipio de Medellin, un municipio donde el empuje y verraquera es un referente muy importante de los habitantes de esta zona.

Ella trabaja todos los días en horarios muy variados y siempre está ocupada en algún servicio ya que es muy solicitada por su buen trabajo.

Solicita un aliento económico para realizar la compra de un modulo para manicure y pedicura, así podrá prestar un mejor servicio y podrá mantener a flote su servicio.

Hoy en día se siente feliz por el buen trabajo que hasta ahora ha realizado y que le ha permitido gozar de un trabajo más estable.

Con un crédito podrás apoyar a Ana a continuar con su proyecto de vida!¡
texts.en:
In her tireless pursuit of a better life and financial stability for her 6-year-old daughter, Ana set up a nail and hair salon. She offers her services in a small place in Medellin, a district where having a strong will is a quality considered very important among its inhabitants.

She works everyday with a flexible schedule and she is always busy offering some of her services. She is greatly sought-after because of the quality of her work. 

She is requesting financial aid to buy manicure and pedicure furniture so that she can offer a better service and keep her business going.

Currently she feels happy for the good work she has been doing, that has allowed her to enjoy a stable job.

With a loan you can help Ana to continue with her life plans!

loans.use: to buy manicure and pedicure furniture so that she can offer a better service

loans.name: Jagat Janani Group-D

texts.en:
Dalimba is a 44-year-old widow woman who lives with her brother's family. She took over the family's responsibility after the death of her husband. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

She did not want to be a burden on her brother, so she started a tailoring service 12 years ago. From this business, she earns 2,000 INR per month. 

Dalimba requested a loan of 12,000 INR for each member through People's Forum. She will buy an extra sewing machine and more materials like fabric, thread, needles, etc., for her sewing business. Dalimba has a plan to start a tailoring training center, so she wants to take a loan for that. 

In the future, Dalimba would like to save enough money so she can help and support her brother's family and be able to live independently.

The other member, Puspanjali, is engaged in paddy cultivation.

loans.use: to buy an extra sewing machine and more materials like fabric, thread, needles, etc., for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Maa Thakurani Group-C

texts.en:
Subay, the lady standing first from the left, is a 29-year-old woman living with her husband, father-in-law and two children in a small village in the Koraput District of Odisha, India. She is engaged in a food stall where she sells breakfast and snacks and earns 3,000 INR per month.

She wants to expand her business so that she can make more money and can get her children admitted in a school. She is a very responsible and hardworking woman. She shares a part of the responsibility for all the family’s expenses. She has applied for a loan to purchase a refrigerator so that she can sell cold drinks and milk-made foods.

Mangari and Sanadei are engaged in milk-selling and vegetable-selling respectively.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator for her food stall.

loans.name: Maa Bhabani Group-B

texts.en:
For 14 years, Shanti worked alongside her husband running a medium-sized restaurant, or as the locals say, a “hotel business” in their town in Odisha, a state in Eastern India. Together, they were well known and respected members of the community. In 2004, however, her husband passed away, leaving her with the business to manage and two daughters to support on her own. She was devastated. 

Shanti is a strong woman, but it is a lot of pressure to run a business with six employees and support her daughters, especially in a community where most of the businesses are run by men. Nevertheless, she is determined to fulfill the dream of her late husband to renovate and improve the hotel. They used to envision turning it into a full-service, air-conditioned establishment. 

Through hard work and the help of her daughters, she has saved 70,000 INR for this project and is taking out this loan which totals 12,000 INR for each member. With this, she will have enough to build new counters and buy an air conditioner. She is so grateful for Kiva and People’s Forum for reaching out to widows like her and helping them improve their livelihoods.

The lady standing in middle is Shanti.

loans.use: to pay for an air conditioner and to build new counters for her restaurant.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Akossiwa est une femme mariée âgée de 32 ans et vit à Sagbado avec ses deux enfants. Pour subvenir aux charges de sa famille, Akossiwa vend de la pate emballée pour gagner la rentabilité nécessaire pour leur épanouissement. Akossiwa s’approvisionne une fois par mois au marché. Pour acheter des bols de maïs et tirer plus de profits, Akossiwa demande ce prêt pour atteindre ses objectifs afin d’aider son mari dans l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en: Akossiwa is a 32-year old married woman. She lives in Sagbado with her two children. In order to support her family, Akossiwa sells wrapped corn mush in order to be able to earn a revenue necessary to ensure the family’s well-being. Akossiwa stocks up once a month at the market. In order to buy bowls of corn and increase her revenus, Akossiwa is seeking this loan with the goal of helping her husband to pay for their children’s education.

loans.use: to buy 50 bowls of corn.

loans.name: Phong's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phong, born in 1981, is a Thai ethnic woman. Her family consists of four members, including her husband, her son, her daughter and herself. Now the family is living in Mai Son district, Son La province.

Her family’s main occupation is cultivation and breeding; the income is just enough to cover food for the whole family and save a little amount left. However, the saved amount is not enough to buy fertilizer for the coming crop of coffee. Therefore, she really wants to borrow a loan to invest in buying fertilizer for the coffee.

She expects that, thanks to the loan amount which will help her family invest effectively with high productivity, the harvest of coffee in this year will bring high yield, double the previous year. For her side, she will work hard to get money to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: to invest in buying fertilizer for coffee plants

loans.name: Suhidoo - Kunkuna/bimbilla Group

texts.en:
Adombiri is a 30-year-old hardworking woman from Bimbilla in Ghana's Northern Region. Adombiri is married and has one child. She is the one in the group picture placing her hand on the milled rice among members squatting.

Adombiri is a member of a parboiled rice processing group that has been in business for the last five years. The name of the group is Suhidoo - Kunkuna/Bimbilla. She earns a good profit from the business simply because the group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to process high quality parboiled rice for the Ghanaian local market.

Adombiri and Suhidoo - Kunkuna/Bimbilla Group have asked for a loan of GHS 6,200. Adombiri’s share of the loan is GHS 500, which would be used to buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing. Adombiri aspires to build a large warehouse to store enough quantities of paddy rice for processing. With this loan, she will increase her income so as to repay this loan and support her family with good health care and education.

Adombiri thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing.

loans.name: Maa Bhabani Group-A

texts.en:
Sail, the lady standing middle in the photo, is 48 years old. She is a widow who lives with her two children, aged 19 years and 16 years. She has taken care of and brought up her children with great effort and love. 

Once they were older, she had more free time, so she began to teach herself different crafts such as sewing, decorating terracotta statues of Lord Jagannath, and other handicrafts. Little by little, she created her products and began to sell them to her neighbors and friends. She added in clothing, which added to her income. This has generated income which supports her household finances. 

The loan she is seeking will be used to invest in the purchase of supplies and merchandise at wholesale as Samuka (used for decoration) items, wood, fabric, thread, paint, etc. This will allow her to continue to work and offer more variety to her customers. It will also allow her to fill the orders she already has and will increase her sales and income. 

Sail states that her future plans are to strengthen and grow her business even more, with the aim of generating job opportunities for some family members who need a job, and thereby, improving the quality of life for her whole family.

loans.use: to buy wholesale supplies and merchandise such as Samuka decoration items, wood, fabric, thread, paint, etc.

loans.name: San Pablo Group

texts.en:
San Pedro Jocopilas is a small community outside of Quiche in the western highlands of Gutatemala. Quiche is one of the most poverty stricken of the country’s 23 departments, with an incidence of poverty of over 80 percent. The department, named after the Maya-K’iche people, has a diverse and complicated history. Most recently, in the 1980’s, violence from the civil war tore through the region, displacing and killing thousands of indigenous people. 	  

In San Pedro Jocopilas, eight indigenous K’iche women have joined to form the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank San Pablo. The women, who are finishing their third loan cycle with Friendship Bridge, are applying for another loan to support their various small business. 

Juana, a 28-year-old member of San Pablo, has been making and selling typical Maya-K’iche skirts for over three years. When Juana started her business, she sewed and sold artisanal skirts to small stores and vendors in Santa Cruz and other surrounding towns. In the next few years, using the connections she made as a supplier, she expanded her business to employ three women from a small rural community who have helped her expand her production capacity. Juana is applying for another loan to buy the necessary capital to continue producing and selling traditional skirts. With this loan, Juana is hoping to maintain her existing business and to build capital in order to potentially open her own storefront. With the support if Kiva investors, Juana will have the opportunity to continue gaining business experience and to start working toward her goal of opening her own store.

The eight unified women of the Trust Bank are dedicated to working together and supporting each other through the difficulties they face trying to maintain and grow their business. Additionally, their loan officer, as part of Friendship Bridge’s microcredit plus program, provides the women with monthly educational training in their native language of K’iche. The monthly non-formal education covers topics ranging from women’s empowerment, financial literacy, and health and medicinal plants.

loans.use: to buy the necessary capital to continue producing and selling traditional skirts.

loans.name: Epouses Des Enseignants N° 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le GIE « Epouses des enseignants n°6 », regroupent des femmes enseignantes et/ou dont les maris sont enseignants. Ce rassemblement est né il y a quelques années et les activités divergent selon les membres.
Depuis l’âge de 14 ans, la dame Dieynabou, qui est la présidente du GIE et de ce sous-groupe n°6, avait déjà commencé à accompagner sa maman dans ses activités commerciales. Âgée maintenant de 45 ans, elle s’est améliorer dans cette dynamique jusqu’à nos jours, elle fait de la teinture et de la vente de tissus teints. Elle est formatrice  et secrétaire élue à la chambre des Métiers.
Elle a ouvert une cantine devant chez elle où elle vend des tissus, des colliers d’art…
Dieynaba participe volontairement aux charges de la maison.
 Elle a comme objectif majeur d’ouvrir un centre de formation en teinture et d’appui aux femmes promotrices de projets.
texts.en:
The borrowers’ group "Teachers’ spouses #6" is composed of women who are   teachers themselves and/or are married to teachers. This group was created a few years ago, and its members  are engaged in various types of business activities.

 Mrs. Dieynabou, who is the leader of this borrowers’ association and its subgroup # 6, started working alongside her mother from the age of 14 on. 
At present she is 45 years and has been growing her business for all these years. She dyes fabric for sale. She provides training and serves as elected secretary of the local Chamber of Trades.

She opened a small shop in front of her house where she sells fabric, artisanal necklaces etc. Dieynabou is glad to contribute to the household budget. Her main goal is to open a training center in fabric dyeing and provide support to women engaged in business activities.

loans.use: to buy products needed to dye fabric for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 52-year-old Fatmata. She is married and has four children aged 33, 31, 29 and 23 years. In 2006, she established her baby clothing business, which she began because she wants to help her husband with some responsibilities. Her business is located close to a children’s hospital in the outskirts of town and her main customers are pregnant women and suckling mothers. Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 780,000 every month. 

Fatmata requires a loan of SLL 5,000,000 in order to buy more diapers, baby oil, baby powder and napkins for resale. She hopes that this loan will help her to meet the demand of her customers. She still plans to develop and build her own shop, and to educate her children up to a university level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more baby items

loans.name: Delianita

texts.en:
Delianita is 49 years old and married with four children, all of whom are in school. She works very hard to provide for them.

Delianita runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy item to sell in her general store like canned goods, condiments, home care products and other groceries.

Delianita has been in this business for two years now.

In the future, Delianita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy item to sell in her general store like canned goods, condiments, home care products and other groceries.

loans.name: Jose David

texts.es:
José, de 22 años de edad, es estudiante y estudio hasta bachillerato, está acompañado y junto con su pareja tienen un hijo.- José, vive con su suegra y dos cuñados.

José, trabaja en la platanera de monitoreo agrícola en su comunidad desde hace un año, este trabajo lo aprendió para darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.- Jose, viaja en bicicleta 3 kilómetros para llegar hasta su lugar de trabajo, en el horario de 6:00 a.m. a 1:00 p.m. todos los días y en sus ratos libres, le ayuda a su esposa en los quehaceres del hogar.

El crédito que está solicitando es para comprar puertas e instalar la energia electrica, para la casita que está construyendo.

El sueño de José, es seguir estudiando y sacar una carrera universitaria, para tener mejores posibilidades de trabajo.
texts.en:
José, 22, finished high school. He is in a relationship and has a son. José lives with his mother-in-law and two brothers-in-law.

He has been working as a supervisor for a local banana plantation for a year. He learned this activity thinking of improving his family’s living conditions. José has to travel 3 km (1.9 miles) by bike to go to work. He works from 06:00 am until 01:00 pm, every day. When he is free, he helps his wife with the household chores.

José is requesting a loan to buy doors and install the electrical system of a house he is building. His dream is to continue studying and graduate from the university, in order to have better job opportunities.

loans.use: to buy doors and install the electrical system of a house he is building.

loans.name: Jagat Janani Group-A

texts.en:
Madhabi, the lady standing first from the left, is a 48-year-old lady who lives with her husband and two sons, age 17 years and 19 years. Her sons are attending school. She is the only source of income for her family.

Madhabi is engaged in a saree-selling business, and she sells different types of sarees (traditional clothing for Indian women) from her house. She has been in the business of selling sarees for ten years.

She is applying for a loan to buy different types and styles of sarees in bulk to provide more choice of products to meet customer demand. This loan part will help her improve her sales and enable her to offer a new product line to her customers. Her objective is to expand the business and include new products, such as kurta, pants, and shirts to her existing business.

She wants to save for her sons' educations with the increased revenues from the increased sales supported by the new products.

loans.use: to buy different types and styles of sarees in bulk to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase compost, Formula 54, and Alto 100 for her coffee cultivation.

loans.name: Epouses Des Enseignants N°7 Group

texts.fr:
Le GIE Epouses des enseignants n°7, rassemble des enseignantes et/ou des épouses d’enseignants qui s’activent dans le commerce. Elles se sont regroupées en réseaux pour solidariser mais aussi pour pouvoir bénéficier de financements plus facilement. Elles viennent pour la première fois à l’IMCEC pour solliciter un crédit. 
 Aida, âgée de 31 ans est la responsable du sous groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants, une fille et un garçon âgés respectivement de 6 ans et 2 ans. Elle évolue depuis plus de 5 ans dans le commerce de produits halieutiques comme c’est la principale activité dans cette zone. Elle a des parents qui sont dans la capitale, et comme le produit est très prisé et rare dans cette localité, elle le liquide rapidement et la clientèle en redemande. C’est pourquoi, elle envisage d’augmenter son capital pour développer son activité.
texts.en:
The Epouses des Enseignants (Wives of Teachers) no.7 GIE (economic interest group) is made up of teachers/and or teachers' wives who have trading businesses. They are grouped in networks to make them jointly liable for borrowings but also to enable them to get financing more easily. They are for the first time turning to IMCEC to request a loan.

Aida is 31 years old and the leader of the sub-group. She is married and mother to two children, a girl and a boy, aged six and two years old respectively. For the past five years she has been building up a business selling fish products, as this is the main activity in this area. She has parents who are in the capital, and as such products are popular but rare in this town, she sells her goods quickly and customers request more. This is why she is planning to increase her capital to develop this business.

loans.use: to buy seafood to resell in the capital.

loans.name: Silvia Yesenia

texts.es: Silvia de 31 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con su hija, ella trabaja en una empresa privada desde hace mas de 2 años, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra salir adelante, ella quiere mejorar su vivienda encementando y colocando el techo en el lugar que muestra la fotografía, pero con lo que obtiene de su sueldo no le alcanza para realizarlo por esa razón solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito para la compra de cemento, arena, laminas, polines y pago de mano de obra y así ella y su hija puedan vivir más cómodas y seguras.
texts.en:
Silvia, 31, is a single mother. She owns a house where she lives with her daughter. Silvia has been working for a private company for more than two years. She gets ahead with what she earns.

Silvia wants to improve her home by laying a concrete floor and building a roof over the area that is shown in the picture. However, she does not earn enough, and this is why she is requesting a loan at Integral. She will buy cement, sand, metal sheets and beams, and pay for the labor. She and her daughter will now live a safer and more comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, metal sheets and beams, and pay for the labor needed to build a roof.

loans.name: Epouses Des Enseignants N°8 Group

texts.fr:
Le GIE Epouses des enseignants n°8, rassemble des enseignantes et/ou des épouses d’enseignants qui s’activent dans le commerce. Elles se sont regroupées en réseaux pour solidariser mais aussi pour pouvoir bénéficier de financements plus facilement. Elles viennent pour la première fois à l’IMCEC pour solliciter un crédit. 
Elles ont comme responsable, la dame Ndèye Rokhaya, mariée et mère de 6 enfants, qui s’active dans le commerce. Elle a acquis une expérience de plus de 10 ans dans ce domaine qui consiste à vendre du poisson séché et fumé et des fruits de mer. Elle écoule ses produits dans la capitale et dans les zones un peu éloignées de la petite cote.
Sa participation allant à l’encontre de ses enfants, elle a comme soucis majeur, de les appuyer pour qu’ils étudient et réussissent dans la vie.
texts.en:
The Epouses des Enseignants (Teachers' Wives) no. 8 GIE (economic interest group) is made up of teachers and/or teachers' wives who are active traders. They grouped themselves into networks so that they could share joint liability for borrowing but also get funding more easily. They have turned to IMCEC for the first time in order to request a loan.

Their leader is Ndèye Rokhaya, who is married and mother to six children, is an active trader. She has built up an experience of over ten years in the field of selling dried and smoked fish as well as seafood. She sells off her stock in the capital and in areas not too near the small coast. Her profits go towards helping her children, and her major concern is to be able to support them so they can study and succeed in life.

loans.use: to buy fish products: dried and smoked fish, to resell.

loans.name: Leanette

texts.en:
Leanette is a very hardworking entrepreneur from Pasay, Philippines. She is 35 years old and has children. She is married to Alvin, and they are supporting their children through all their hard work in business. They operate a junk shop to provide income for their everyday needs and expenses. 

Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines, and while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, and papers. They sell these items to junk shops for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean, and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries and factories. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Leanette is taking out a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy recyclable materials from collectors. 

In the future, she hopes that her business will continue to become successful, and she dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and also draws strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To procure the recyclable materials she needs for her business.

loans.name: Enecita

texts.en:
Enecita is a married woman with one child in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Enecita is 39 years old now.

Enecita has a buy-and-sell coconut shell business in the Philippines. Enecita requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy coconut shells to sell.

Enecita has been in this business for two years. In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy coconut shells to sell.

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business making dried fish in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to make dried fish for her business.

Letecia has been in this business for nine years. She earns more income from fishing.

Letecia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to make dried fish

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 48 years old, married, and has four children. She is in the agricultural business of farming rice in the Philippines. Estrella has requested a PHP 6,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

She has been in this business for 22 years now, and has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Estrella would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Maria Criste

texts.en:
Maria Criste is 21 years old and married with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a business buying and selling cellular phone accessories in the Philippines. 

Maria Criste has requested a PHP 14,500 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more accessories to sell. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. She has been in this business for six years. Maria Criste would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more cell phone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is a married woman with two children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Evangeline is 23 years old and her children are both in school.

Evangeline has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Evangeline requested a PHP 6,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy boxes of fish to sell in her food stall.

Evangeline has been in this business for two years. In the future, Evangeline would like to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to buy boxes of fish to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Jane Racel

texts.en:
Jane Racel is 23 years old, with one child who is in school. She works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her general store like shampoo, biscuits and other groceries.

Jane Racel has been in this business for five years now.  In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store like shampoo, biscuits and other groceries.

loans.name: Maa Bhabani Group-C

texts.en:
Santoshi, the lady standing middle in the photo, is a 36-year-old, married woman living with her husband and two children in a village in Odisha, a state in Eastern India. Together, they all make bags from paper and also run a small shop selling fresh bodi and papad, which are traditional spicy snacks made from ground wheat and lentils. They also make paper carry-bags that they sell to other business owners in their village. The family makes enough to get by on, but still struggle to meet monthly expenses, as they belong to a poor family and must support themselves. 

Santoshi is therefore asking for a loan of 12,000 INR for each group member. She will begin to purchase items in bulk and expand the business. Particularly, items like flour, salt, and oil will be much cheaper in large amounts, and she will be able to earn a larger profit. She hopes to build up the business into one of the main bodi shops in town, while continuing to bring in income from the paper bags.

Jainasen and Sharojin are also engaged in the same type of business as Santoshi.

loans.use: To pay for purchasing items like flour, salt, oil, and spices for her snacks business.

loans.name: Epouses Des Enseignants N° 9 Group

texts.fr:
Le GIE Epouses des enseignants n°9, rassemble des enseignantes et/ou des épouses d’enseignants qui s’activent dans le commerce. Elles se sont regroupées en réseaux pour solidariser mais aussi pour pouvoir bénéficier de financements plus facilement. Elles viennent pour la première fois à l’IMCEC pour solliciter un crédit. 
Madame Thiaba est enseignante de profession, elle est aussi mariée à un enseignant. Elle est mère de 3 enfants dont l’ainé et le cadet sont âgées respectivement de 16 ans et 8 ans. Elle s’active aussi dans le commerce de produits de mer : poissons séchés et fumés, moule et divers autres produits. Elle met en sachets pour placer chez ses collègues enseignants qui paient à la fin du mois. Elle participe volontairement à la dépense quotidienne.
Thiaba a un autre projet en tête qu’elle désire réaliser un jour, c’est de devenir une grande couturière et d’ouvrir un atelier de renommé.
texts.en:
The Epouses des Enseignants (Teachers' Wives) no. 9 GIE (economic interest group) is made up of teachers and/or teachers' wives who are active traders. They grouped themselves into networks so that they could share joint liability for borrowing but also get funding more easily. They have turned to IMCEC for the first time in order to request a loan.

Thiaba is a teacher by profession and she is also married to a teacher. She is mother to three children, the eldest of whom is 16 years old and the youngest eight. She also trades in sea produc": dried and smoked fish, mussels and various other products. She puts her goods into sachets to give to her teaching colleagues and they pay her at the end of the month. She contributes voluntarily to the daily expenses. 

Thiaba has another plan in mind that she would like to put in place in the future, that is to become a quality seamistress and open a reputable workshop.

loans.use: to buy fish products for resale (dried and smoked fish...)
